revisions.*:
'''Papa Charlie Jackson''' (November 10, 1887 – May 7, 1938)<ref>Eagle, Bob L., LeBlanc, Eric S. (2013). ''Blues: A Regional Experience''. ABC-CLIO. p. 513. ISBN 0313344248.</ref> was an early [[United States|American]] [[blues]]man and [[songster]] who accompanied himself with a [[banjo guitar]], a guitar, or a [[ukulele]]. His [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] career began in 1924.<ref name="Russell"/>  Much of his life remains a mystery, but it is probable that he was born in [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]], and died in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] in 1938.<ref name="amg">[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p385/biography|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic biography - accessed January 2008]</ref>

==Career==
Born '''William Henry Jackson''',<ref name="para">[http://www.paramountshome.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=82:william-henry-qpapa-charlieq-jackson&catid=45:new-york-recording-laboratoriesartist&Itemid=54 Paramountshome website], retrieved August 19, 2012.</ref> he originally performed in [[Minstrel show|minstrel]] and [[medicine show]]s.<ref name="Harris263">[[Sheldon Harris (music historian)|Harris, Sheldon]] (1994). ''Blues Who's Who'' (Revised Ed.). New York: Da Capo Press. p. 263. ISBN  0-306-80155-8</ref> From the early 1920s into the 1930s, Jackson played frequent club dates in Chicago, and was noted for [[busking]] at Chicago's [[Maxwell Street|Maxwell Street Market]].<ref name="Russell"/> In August 1924, he recorded the commercially-successful "Airy Man Blues" and "Papa's Lawdy Lawdy Blues" for [[Paramount Records]]. One of his following tracks, "[[Salty Dog Blues]]", became his most famous song. Among his recordings are several in which he accompanied [[classic female blues]] singers such as [[Ida Cox]], [[Hattie McDaniel]], and [[Ma Rainey]].<ref name="Russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| page= 123
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref>

Blues writer Bruce Eder says that Jackson achieved "a musical peak of sorts in September of 1929 when he got to record with his longtime idol, [[Blind Blake|Blind (Arthur) Blake]], often known as the king of ragtime guitar during this period. 'Papa Charlie and Blind Blake Talk About It' parts one and two are among the most unusual sides of the late '20s, containing elements of blues jam session, hokum recording, and ragtime".<ref name="amg"/> A few more recordings for the Paramount label followed in 1929 and 1930.<ref name="Harris263" /> In 1934 he recorded for [[Okeh Records]], and the following year he recorded with [[Big Bill Broonzy]].<ref name="Harris263" />
Altogether, Jackson recorded 66 [[Side (recording)|side]]s during his career.

==Legacy==
Jackson was an influential figure in blues music, the first blues musician to make records.<ref name="amg" /> He was one of the first musicians of the "Hokum" genre,<ref name="redhotjazz">[http://www.redhotjazz.com/jackson.html biography at Red Hot Jazz], retrieved August 19, 2012.</ref> which uses comic, often sexually suggestive lyrics and lively, danceable rhythms.<ref>Evans, David. (2005). ''The NPR curious listener's guide to blues''. Penguin. p. 74. ISBN 039953072X.</ref> He wrote or was the first to record several songs that became blues standards, including "Spoonful" and "Salty Dog".<ref>Herzhaft, G., Harris, P., Haussler, J., & Mikofsky, A. J. (1997). ''Encyclopedia of the blues''. Fayetteville, AR: University of Arkansas Press. p. 93. ISBN 1557284520.</ref> Nonetheless, he has received little attention from blues historians.<ref name="redhotjazz" />

Jackson's "Shake That Thing" was [[cover version|covered]] by [[Mother McCree's Uptown Jug Champions (album)|Mother McCree's Uptown Jug Champions]] in 1964. "Loan Me Your Heart" appeared on [[The Wildparty Sheiks]] eponymous album in 2002. The [[Carolina Chocolate Drops]] recorded "Your Baby Ain't Sweet Like Mine" on their [[Grammy Award]] winning 2010 album, ''[[Genuine Negro Jig]]'', and often played the song in interviews after its release.

In 1973 Jackson's song "Shake That Thing" was briefly featured in the ''[[Sanford and Son]]'' episode, "The Blind Mellow Jelly Collection". Fred, played by [[Redd Foxx]], could be seen dancing and singing to it at the beginning of the episode.
